This post explores advanced optimization techniques that go beyond basic ODT implementation.

1. The Challenge: Scaling to 2400MT/s+At 2400MT/s, the unit interval (UI) is approximately 417ps. Within this tiny window, we must account for: Controller output jitter: 30-50psPCB trace delay variations: 20-40psNAND input buffer setup/hold: 50-80psClock skew: 20-30psPower supply noise: 10-20psThe remaining margin for actual data transmission can be less than 200ps, making every optimization critical. At these frequencies, transmission line effects like signal reflection can completely close the data eye diagram. On-Die Termination (ODT) is the critical hardware mechanism designed to mitigate these effects.

1. The Physics of ReflectionWhen a high-speed signal reaches the end of a transmission line (the NAND die), any impedance mismatch between the PCB trace (typically 50Ω) and the high-impedance input buffer causes the signal to reflect back. This creates “ringing” and “intersymbol interference (ISI),” eroding the tDS (Data Setup) and tDH (Data Hold) margins.
